_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Homeland Energy Solutions, LLC (HES) is an ethanol fuel production plant located in Lawler, Iowa in Chickasaw County. HES has completed a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for chemicals stored on-site that could exceed reporting thresholds as a requirement of Section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990. HES began operations in 2009.  The initial RMP Submittal completed 4/23/2009.  This RMP resubmission includes natural gasoline (denaturant) as a flammable maxture because it includes isopentane and has an NFPA rating of 4.



Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

HES is committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol fuel production process. HES uses natural gasoline as a denaturant to make ethanol produced at the facility unfit for human consumption. HES also uses anhydrous ammonia for pH control directly in the process.

In the event of a significant emergency, including an accidental release of flammable or toxic materials, it is the policy of HES to notify appropriate authorities and evacuate all employees at the facility.



Facility and Regulated Substances Handled

As previously mentioned, HES's ethanol production process requires use of a denaturant (most commonly natural gasoline) to render ethanol produced by the facility unfit for human consumption. The natural gasoline is stored in an aboveground tank as a liquid under atmospheric pressure and is mixed with ethanol prior to transport. The denaturant tank is located in the facility's on-site tank farm area which is equipped with secondary containment. The supply and chemical make-up of denaturant is dependent upon market rates and the source of the natural gasoline, making it difficult for HES to foresee with much certainty the specific chemical makeup of its denaturant. Denaturant used by the ethanol industry commonly contains pentane, isopentane, and/or butane in varying percentages.HES has

chosen to file this RMP based on the MSDS for the natural gasoline it currently uses.  

Emergency response programs for the modeled release scenarios have been prepared and implemented. HES has coordinated emergency response with local authorities and responding agencies and will conduct periodic drills.



General Accidental Release Prevention Program

Through completion of this RMP and similar efforts regulated by OSHA's Process Safety Management standard at 29 CFR 1910.119, HES has complied with the EPA requirements at 40 CFR Part 68. Process safety information, safe work practices such as Hot Work, Confined Space Entry and Lockout/Tagout, and operations and maintenance procedures are documented on-site. Periodic functions such as process hazard analyses (PHA), training, management of change, pre-startup safety reviews, and incident investigation are conducted on a regular basis. A PHA for a variety of hazardous processes at the facility was conducted in November 2011. Compliance audits of the RMP Prevention Program will be conducted on a regular basis to assure compliance with EPA and OSHA regulations.



Five Year Accident History

HES does not have a history of accidents involving regulated chemcials which may have caused death, injuries, environmental or property damage, evacuations or in-place sheltering.



Emergency Response Program

HES has developed response efforts to a variety of potential scenarios involving hazardous substances stored and used at the facility. These efforts have been coordinated with state and federal regulating agencies and local responders. HES also participates in meetings and planning with Chickasaw County Emergency Management.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety

As previously mentioned, HES is committed to the protection of its employees, the greater community and the environment from hazardous substances used in the ethanol fuel production process. HES management is committed to promoting a safe work environment. HES will co

ntinue to provide its employees with the necessary training, tools, and ongoing support needed to conduct their work safely and to operate the ethanol production process in a safe and efficient manner. In addition, HES has 4 audits per year by third parties: two for safety, one for fire, and one for equipment hazards.
